question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What position did Vladimir Idelson hold in 2045?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

"The Unlikely Rise of a Legal Luminary: The Story of Vladimir Idelson, King's Counsel"

In the esteemed halls of the British legal system, where tradition and prestige reign supreme, a remarkable individual has earned the highest honor bestowed upon a lawyer: King's Counsel. Vladimir Idelson, a man of unyielding dedication and unwavering passion for justice, has risen through the ranks to claim this coveted title. To understand the significance of this achievement, one must delve into the rich history of the British legal system. The honorific of King's Counsel, also known as Queen's Counsel (QC), dates back to the 16th century, when it was first bestowed upon a select group of lawyers who demonstrated exceptional skill and expertise in their field. Today, the title remains a badge of excellence, reserved for those who have consistently demonstrated outstanding advocacy, integrity, and a deep understanding of the law. Vladimir Idelson's journey to becoming a King's Counsel began many years ago, when he first set foot in a British courtroom. With a keen mind and an insatiable thirst for knowledge, he quickly established himself as a formidable advocate, earning the respect of his peers and the admiration of his clients. His tireless work ethic and unwavering commitment to justice soon caught the attention of the legal community, and he began to build a reputation as a leading expert in his field. As Idelson's reputation grew, so did his caseload. He took on complex, high-stakes cases that tested the limits of the law, and consistently delivered results that impressed even the most seasoned judges. His mastery of the courtroom, combined with his ability to distill complex legal concepts into clear, compelling arguments, made him a sought-after advocate for clients from all walks of life. But Idelson's rise to prominence was not without its challenges. He faced formidable opponents, navigated treacherous legal landscapes, and confronted the weight of precedent and tradition. Yet, with each obstacle, he emerged stronger, more resilient, and more determined to uphold the principles of justice. The crowning achievement of Idelson's career came when he was formally appointed as a King's Counsel. This honor, bestowed upon him by the British monarch, recognized his outstanding contributions to the legal profession and his unwavering commitment to upholding the rule of law. The appointment was a testament to his exceptional skill, his unshakeable integrity, and his dedication to the pursuit of justice.

**BERLIN, GERMANY - DECEMBER 2043**

In a surprise move, Vladimir Idelson, a renowned British QC, has announced his resignation from the German Bundestag, effective immediately. Idelson, who has held the position of deputy in the German parliament since June 2030, has been a vocal advocate for European cooperation and human rights. During his 13-year tenure, Idelson has been instrumental in shaping key legislation, including the landmark "European Union Climate Accord" and the "Refugee Protection Act". His expertise in international law has been invaluable to the Bundestag, and his departure will be deeply felt. In an exclusive interview with our correspondent, Idelson cited personal reasons for his decision, stating, "After 13 incredible years, I feel it's time for me to return to my roots and focus on my family and private practice. I'm proud of what we've achieved, but I'm also aware that there's still much work to be done." Idelson's resignation has sent shockwaves through the German political establishment, with many of his colleagues paying tribute to his dedication and commitment. "Vladimir has been an inspiration to us all," said Chancellor Anna Schulz. "His unique perspective and expertise have enriched our debates and informed our decisions. He will be deeply missed." According to data from the Bundestag, Idelson has participated in over 500 parliamentary sessions, spoken in over 200 debates, and sponsored or co-sponsored over 50 bills. His influence extends beyond the Bundestag, with many European leaders seeking his counsel on matters of international law and diplomacy. As Idelson departs, speculation is rife about his potential successor. Insiders suggest that a special election will be held in the coming months to fill the vacant seat. In the meantime, Idelson's legacy will continue to shape German politics, and his contributions to European cooperation will be remembered for years to come. In a parting statement, Idelson said, "I'm grateful for the trust the German people have placed in me.
